stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on three tasks: (1) squeezing out a 5 % render-time gain by fixing Mario 64’s culling math and moving culling/shadow data into each object, (2) collaborating with Biobak on a complete rebuild of the Star-Select menu (new background model, scrolling animation, kerning, 60 FPS), and (3) prototyping an oil-wave hazard that fades Mario out and respawns him using a new safe-position algorithm generated with ChatGPT.

development_findings.summary: Corrected the original Mario 64 culling logic (45° FOV instead of 60°) and embedded culling & shadow data in the object struct, saving ~600 µs per frame (~5 % FPS gain, 44→46 FPS).
development_findings.quote: I fixed the culling so now everything that's off-screen is actually getting culled and that saved like 600 microseconds out of like 22,000.

development_findings.summary: New engine now lets shadows and culling radiuses be added to enemies easily, something Fast64 made ‘really annoying’.
development_findings.quote: With my new engine it will be very easy to add them everywhere.

development_findings.summary: Star-Select overhaul: Biobak supplied new layered background; Kaze built a code-driven scrolling system (three tiled models, fly-in animation) at 60 FPS with per-course render functions instead of per-course geolayouts.
development_findings.quote: Maybe instead of having one geolayout per thing, we'll have one render function per thing and the render function is what decides the geolayout.

development_findings.summary: Implemented dynamic kerning and 1.5× mission-text scaling; fixed centering inaccuracies caused by legacy code.
development_findings.quote: Basically I invented better kerning, and this is not used here.

development_findings.summary: Solved visible seam in scrolling background by de-syncing scroll speed from tile size (speed 10 → 9).
development_findings.quote: The seam came from this because it was exactly 10, which means one update was delayed by a tick.

development_findings.summary: Oil-wave death mechanic: wrote fade-out then respawn system that stores the last ‘safe’ triangle if distance from edges exceeds a threshold; avoids checkpoints and moving-platform issues.
development_findings.quote: We find the triangle Mario’s on, see if his distance from the edge is bigger than a threshold; if it is, that's a valid respawn point.

development_findings.summary: Used ChatGPT to generate edge-distance algorithm, drastically speeding implementation.
development_findings.quote: That is so insane. You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself, and this is why I like ChatGPT.

development_findings.summary: Camera now maintains angle on death, looks at spot of failure, and is prevented from dipping below the oil surface for clarity.
development_findings.quote: I don’t want the camera to go under the oil. I want it to just point down at the oil and have it be like, look, there goes Mario.
We're missing like four and a half courses so we're like over 70 % done at this point.

development_findings.summary: Considering decal-based ‘oil on Mario’ effect rendered as a second model; deferred to polish phase.
development_findings.quote: Add a decal Mario object that can render in the exact same place as normal Mario … You can fade this decal in or out to render effects over Mario.

context_findings.summary: Accidentally scheduled multiple shorts on same day, hurting views; expresses frustration with YouTube scheduling mishap.
context_findings.quote: I'm really sad that I messed up today and accidentally scheduled two videos on the shorts channel … that's why it's getting less views than it should.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: avoids engaging haters because escalation is easy in modern world; stresses respect for safety.
context_findings.quote: If you have someone who really hates you, you should not engage with them, because … they might actually just murder you.

context_findings.summary: Design principle: keep controls simple (one button = one output); refuses extra camera buttons to avoid ‘tool-feel’.
context_findings.quote: I think I want to stick to the one-button, one-output philosophy.

context_findings.summary: Technical stance: prefers C++ over Unreal Blueprints, calling Blueprints unsuitable for serious programming.
context_findings.quote: Blueprints are not for programming … it's gonna be slower, less performant, and you’ll get a spaghetti salad.

context_findings.summary: Personal life: grew up by the sea in Germany for ~25 years, now lives in Canada; took Zeina to a seal rescue station during visit.
context_findings.quote: Yeah, the city I live in is right at the sea; when Zeina was over here I took her to see the seals.

biobak.summary: Delivered new Star-Select background models/textures and pushed for visual tweaks (clouds, texture alignment, mission-text placement).
biobak.quote: I said the Star Select we have is boring as shit, so look at this—how cool is that?

biobak.summary: Requested specific layout (logo high, mission text lower); ongoing back-and-forth with Kaze on centering and scaling.

key_stories.title: A 5 % Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While profiling render time, Kaze discovered Mario 64’s original culling maths were wrong. By correcting the FOV assumption and embedding culling/shadow data inside each object, he shaved ~600 µs per frame, raising the engine from 44 to 46 FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Frame rate stuck around mid-40s despite prior optimisations.
key_stories.process: Analysed Nintendo’s culling code, found 45° vs 60° mistake; moved culling & shadow checks into object struct to cut RAM iterations.
key_stories.outcome: Stable 5 % speed gain; groundwork for universal enemy shadows.
key_stories.key_quote: I fixed the culling so now everything that's off-screen is actually getting culled and that saved like 600 microseconds.

key_stories.title: Reinventing Star-Select with Biobak
key_stories.summary: The original menu felt bland, so Biobak produced a vibrant background. Kaze built a 60 FPS scrolling system, fought alignment, kerning, and seams, ultimately achieving a polished, fly-in animation that sets the game’s mood.
key_stories.challenge: Old Star-Select looked ‘boring as shit’ and wasn’t performant.
key_stories.process: Imported Biobak’s models, switched to code-driven render function, tiled three backgrounds, corrected kerning, and adjusted text/star placement through iterative testing.
key_stories.outcome: A visually rich, smooth 60 FPS menu ready for per-course variants.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine entering this level for the first time … and then you see this and the cut-in plays—it's gonna be so impressive.

key_stories.title: ChatGPT Saves the Oil Wave
key_stories.summary: Designing an oil pit that fades Mario out required a robust ‘last safe spot’ algorithm. Instead of writing edge-distance math from scratch, Kaze asked ChatGPT, integrated the code, and had a working prototype within minutes.
key_stories.challenge: Need to respawn Mario logically without traditional checkpoints, avoiding tiny triangles and moving platforms.
key_stories.process: Defined requirement, prompted ChatGPT for edge-distance calculation, integrated, tested, and fine-tuned camera and animations.
key_stories.outcome: Reliable fade-out/respawn system; proof that AI tools can accelerate low-level tasks.
key_stories.key_quote: That is so insane—you guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself, and this is why I like ChatGPT.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his ‘new engine’ allows easy shadows and culling radiuses, unlike Fast64.
questions: What motivated building a new engine instead of extending Fast64?
How is the new engine architected to allow these optimisations?
What other Fast64 pain points did it aim to solve?
Will it be open-sourced or shared with the community?

open_questions.context: Engine now supports enemy shadows but none are implemented yet.
questions: What is the timeline to add shadows to all enemies?
Any creative uses beyond simple circular shadows?
Performance impact expectations?

open_questions.context: Several iterations with Biobak; still debating mission-text size, clouds, gradients.
questions: What final aesthetic are you aiming for—nostalgic or modern?
How do art and code constrain each other in this menu?
Will music or SFX be customised per course?

open_questions.context: Current prototype lacks texture and optional ‘oily Mario’ decal.
questions: What texture style will the oil wave use?
Will Mario carry visual ‘oil’ after respawn?
How does the hazard integrate with level pacing and difficulty?
Which specific courses remain?
What design challenges are anticipated?
How is workload divided among team members for these?

open_questions.context: Kaze mused about running Delfino Plaza at 30 FPS with custom microcode.
questions: Is this purely hypothetical or part of the roadmap?
What microcode tricks are planned for Return to Yoshi’s Island?
What is the target framerate for main gameplay?

open_questions.context: Stream shows live iteration with Biobak; limited on-stream mention of Badub and Zeina.
questions: How does the team coordinate across time zones and disciplines?
What tools and pipelines are in place for art, animation, and music?
How do personal relationships (e.g., Kaze & Zeina) influence feedback loops?

open_questions.topic: Use of AI Tools in Development
open_questions.context: Kaze leveraged ChatGPT for collision math.
questions: How often is AI used in the project?
Any concerns about code quality or originality?
Could AI play a role in level design or QA?
